section.title: Policy application preference configuration
section.p: The following table describes the application preference parameter values available for the policy application.

row.entry: When this system preference is set to June-2019, if the specification CRs are supported. When set to None, none of the following functionality works. This system preference is added to ensure backward compatibility with SMF that does not support the mentioned changes.

For stale session audits, this audit run daily. Sessions are audited to make sure that the PCRF is not holding state in its database for a session that no longer exists on the device that requested the creation of the session.

entry.p: The number of seconds after midnight that the daily auditing of the AF session should begin (for example, 2am = 2 * 60 * 60)

row.entry: The amount of time in seconds that the AF audit will run (for example, 90 minutes = 90* 60)
The number of days old an AF session can be before it is considered “too old” and therefore eligible for auditing.

entry.p: Allows you to change the audit behavior from a daily audit to a more frequent periodic audit.
In “lab mode” when a record is first created, the timestamp is calculated as:
timestampInSecondsSinceEpoch = now + inactivity duration (in seconds, not days) + audit start time + random number in the range (0 - audit length)
When a record is audited and confirmed to still exist/be valid, the timestamp for the next audit is calculated the same way as when the record was first created.
Allows you to change the audit behavior from a daily audit to a more frequent periodic audit.
In “lab mode” when a record is first created, the timestamp is calculated as:
timestampInSecondsSinceEpoch = now + inactivity duration (in seconds, not days) + audit start time + random number in the range (0 - audit length)
When a record is audited and confirmed to still exist/be valid, the timestamp for the next audit is calculated the same way as when the record was first created.

For stale session audits, this audit runs daily. Sessions are audited to make sure that the PCF is not holding state in its database for a session that no longer exists on the device that requested the creation of the session.
Note: When the AM session audit runs, it checks for a PDU association. If no PDU association is found, then PCF deletes the AM session.
The number of seconds after midnight that the daily auditing of the AM session should begin. (For example, 2am = 2 * 60 * 60.)

row.entry: The amount of time in seconds that the AM audit runs. (For example, 90 minutes = 90* 60.)
The number of days where an AM session is considered too old before it is eligible for auditing.

entry.p: It allows you to change the auditing behavior from a daily audit to a more frequent periodic audit. In the lab mode when a record is first created, the timestamp is calculated as: timestampInSecondsSinceEpoch = now + inactivity duration (in seconds, not days) + audit start time + random number in the range (0 - audit length).
When a record is audited and confirmed to be still valid, the timestamp for the next audit is calculated the same way as and when the record was first created.

row.entry: This system preference makes supi optional in the request of npcf_ampolicy_control (N15). If its value is false, then supi is mandatory in request otherwise it is optional.
Bound request missing mapping record strategy

entry.p: Caution: Some aspects of site routing that can be customized but use of this application preference is specific to your network configuration and must be directed by Nokia Services only. Contact the Nokia Services team for more information.
The "Bound request missing mapping record strategy" allows you to specify how routing of messages should occur if no session mapping records are present for the message.
Note: If the message contains a subscription id with a matching device mapping, the device mapping will take precedence over the strategy.

row.entry: Bypass Validation of Origin Host and Realm
When set to true, the policy application bypasses validation of the origin host and realm when processing CCR updates after a failover on the NSN node occurs.
CDR Logging - Include rejected PCRF calls
Flag for whether CDRs should be generated for rejected PCRF calls.
Flag for whether CDRs should be generated for message validation.

Some attributes encode lists of multiple values. When multiple values are recorded, each value starts on a new line. The policy application uses the separators hash tag (":") by default. For example, to log an attribute with the name policyCounters, which could have a list of policy counters, the list returned would be : separated. Each : means another entry. If each entry happens to be a complex entry made up of a name (counter1) and value, the entry is separated by another separator, the “#” by default—CDR Sub-Field Separator 2.

entry.p: Add a new character to act as the first separator.

row.entry: Policy uses the separator "#" by default for a complex entry made up of a name (counter1) and value that is part of a list of sub-enries.

entry.p: Add a new character to act as the second separator.

row.entry: Enables Policy Call Detail Record (CDR) generation when set to true. See the CDR/EDR Reference Guide for more information.
Charging bound session missing mapping record strategy

entry.p: Caution: Some aspects of site routing that can be customized but use of this application preference is specific to your network configuration and must be directed by Nokia Services only. Contact the Nokia Services team for more information.
This application preference allows you to specify how routing of messages should occur if no device mapping records are present for the Gy session.

row.entry: Charging primary session missing mapping record strategy

entry.p: Caution: Some aspects of site routing that can be customized but use of this application preference is specific to your network configuration and must be directed by Nokia Services only. Contact the Nokia Services team for more information.
This application preference allows you to specify how the routing of messages should occur if no session mapping records are present for the message.
Note: If the message contains a subscription id with a matching device mapping, the device mapping will take precedence over the strategy.

row.entry: Allows the policy application to accept Origin-State-Ids from gateways that do not increment in the expected way.

li.p: Client OSI is always validated and is rejected if the “new” value is numerically less than the “old” value. If the change is accepted then sessions associated with the old value are lost. The expected behavior of the policy application is to not accept the connection. If the policy application has learned the identity of a gateway with a specified OSI value and the same gateway (identity) connects with a lower OSI value, CCRs are rejected.

All client OSI changes are valid, and session loss is inevitable. The policy application allows gateways to connect with a lower Origin State-Id than is expected. A message is logged about the gateway reconnecting with an unexpected lower OSI.
Client OSI changes do not cause session loss.

row.entry: The length of time in milliseconds allowed for a distribution of the system configuration. The operation fails if it takes longer than the configured value.

entry.p: Allows you to configure whether both Policy and Charging are to be used in the same policy application.
When both Policy and Charging applications are co-resident in the same policy application, there are scenarios where both applications try to update the same device data, creating a deadlock.

To avoid this deadlock, the flag must be set to true. When policy application is configured to use co-resident Policy and Charging, the first application in a call sends a lock ID to the second application in the Sy message. The second application uses the lock ID in the Sy message from the first application to request the lock for its transaction.
Compatibility mode for Diameter Client parameters.

Certain behaviors on policy application are dependent on the product version that the external Diameter peer supports. By default, the policy application operates in a compatibility mode as specified by the Default 3GPP version.
To enable or disable the UE/NW match service in default mode.

The policy application does not allow service flow requests from both Rx and Gx. By default, this is set to false so that for one service flow, the policy application does not need to wait for the other side before responding to a message from a service flow.

For example, this application preference is used by the policy application when it receives requests for bearer creation. The requests can arrive on the Gx interface or the Rx interface and in some cases a bearer request can be received over both the Gx and the Rx interfaces. When a bearer request arrives over both interfaces, the policy application can impose a slight delay in processing either the Rx or the Gx while it waits for the accompanying request (which may never arrive) on the other interface. When set to false, the policy application processes incoming bearer requests without any delay.

row.entry: Allows you to configure an absolute value that defines the size of a UCS quota allocation value sent to the PCEF for usage arming. This application preference is related to the Quota Allocation Factor (%) application preference such that the value used for usage arming on the PCEF is the lowest of [usage until next threshold, Quota Allocation Factor (%), and Default Volume Quota (bytes)]. Used as a default volume-based quota value, in bytes, when there are no thresholds defined for an Unlimited UCS. It provides an absolute value that does not vary based on UCS size.
Destination Details in OCS Messaging Enabled

entry.p: Defines the behavior of its Destination Host and Destination Realm AVPs when communicating to a remote OCS over the Sy interface. This application preference indicates if the destinationHost is needed in sending to the OCS. The outgoing messages towards the OCS includes the OCS Diameter identities that were learned from the initial establishment of the Sy message.
All all incoming OCS messages that present with new identities, update the Sy session and use these identities in subsequent messages to the OCS.

It is possible for OCS to forward an SNR with different OCS identities, this too results in the Sy session getting updated with the new Diameter identities, which will be used in subsequent messages sent to the OCS.

When the DestinationHost details are included in the initial SLR they are based on whether or not the Rules Engine was used to select the OCS and if those rules included the diameterHost. This indicates that the destinatioHost is included in the initial SLR. This is the only scenario that would include the host in the initial SLR. After that, the inclusion of the Host Identity is based on a application preference attribute and uses the identities that were learned from the far-end OCS.
“true” means It will always include the destination host and realm in all SLR intermediate and STR messages.
“false” means The SLR intermediate and the STR shall be forwarded to the DestinationRealm only.

row.entry: Used to start a device audit at midnight.
A delay that can be added to the Device Audit task start time. For example, if the default device audit start offset time is 1 hr and the start time is midnight, the audit will start at 1 am.
The amount of time in seconds that the device audit will run. Commonly known as the audit window.

entry.p: For example, a 90 minute run would be: 90* 60 = 5400 seconds
The external device data expiry time in the local database.

The number of seconds after which device data expires. If not specified or set to a negative value, the device data never expires. If the expiry time is 0, the device data always expires and a new record is retrieved from the LDAP server. If the expiry time is 300 s, the device data expires 300 s after the session is established with the remote LDAP sever.
Known devices are audited, updated when they expire, and then checked for a session attachment. The Device Expiry time is only applicable to Known LDAP devices.

The Device Expiry time is only applicable to Known LDAP devices. Nokia recommends to always have Unused Device Expiry Time (seconds) timer set equal to or less than the Device Data Expiry Time (seconds) so that it can take effect.

An application preference used to configure the amount of time a CCR-U will wait before returning the Experimental result code 4144 in a CCA. The Diameter Pending Transaction Timeout (milliseconds) is less than the stack timeout so that when the CCR-U stack time-out is reached, a Diameter Too Busy result code is not returned. If the Diameter pending transaction bit is set, the value of the CCR-U wait time-out is changed to the value configured for this application preference. If within the specified duration the RAR answer is not received, the PCRF returns the Experimental result code 4144 in the CCA.
The CCR-U stack time-out sets the duration as the amount of time a CCR-U should wait before being timed-out.

row.entry: Device Unlock Scheduled Task Delay Time (milliseconds)

entry.p: The delay between each interval in which the device unlock task is executed to unlock the device. This application preference is considered only when the application preference "Process CCR-T forcefully" is set to true or when the Diameter pending transaction feature bit is set.

Note: The device unlock task is created when a RAR has taken the lock and CCR-T is being processed forcefully. When RAA is received and CCR-T is still being processed, RAR does not unlock the device and creates a device unlock task to unlock the device later, after completion of CCR-T.

Note: This application preference correlates with the "tpaproperties/pcrf/deviceunlocktask/adjusttime" parameter. The "tpaproperties/pcrf/deviceunlocktask/adjusttime" value defined in the VNF Extension file must be equal to or greater than the value configured for this application preference.

row.entry: Disable PDU UpdateNotify on Session Replacement

By default this value is false and PDU “Update Notify” is sent to the SMF on session replacement. If it is set to true, the replaced PDU session will be removed and “Update Notify” to the SMF will be suppressed.

When this flag is true , the Nchf session re-establishment audit is disabled. That is , the Nchf_SpendingLimitControl_Subscribe-Request Initial retry will not be done by the audit mechanism but will be done on receipt of a N7-Subscribe if the previous Nchf establishment towards the Nchf had failed or timed out.
Disable PDU Session Replacement Of Other Device

This property is used to decide if the PDU session of other device needs to be replaced or not. Currently, PDU sessions of the current device as well as of other devices are considered for replacement. When this property is set as true, other devices PDU sessions are not replaced.

entry.p: When this is set to true, RAR messages are not sent to the gateway when the gateway reboots. A new request is sent to establish a new session for the same subscriber and the existing session is terminated.
When this is set to false, the policy application sends a RAR via Gx when there is a request for IP-CAN session termination by the PCRF.

row.entry: When this is set to true, RAR messages are not sent to the gateway when an existing session is replaced on policy application due to a new request being sent to establish a new session for the same subscriber. This application preference also works when the new request has a different Origin-Host as compared to the previous session that policy application has for the same subscriber.
Disable Gx Session Replacement Of Other Device

entry.p: This property is used to decide if the gx session of other device needs to be replaced or not. Currently, Gx sessions of the current device as well as of other devices are considered for replacement. When this property is set as true, other devices' Gx sessions are not replaced.
Note: This system preference must not be enabled by operators which are using the Rx interface.

row.entry: When this flag is true, the Sy session re-establishment audit is disabled. That is, the SLR-Initial retry will not be done by the audit mechanism but will be done on receipt of a Gx_CCR-U if the previous Sy establishment towards the OCS had failed OR timed out.
Used to enable or disable provisioning EDR generation. See the CDR/EDR Reference Guide for more information.
Used to enable or disable Event Data Record logging when set to true.
If this system preference is set to true, the extended metrics for policy will be dumped into the same metrics.csv file.
External SPR Lookup Enabled For Emergency Call

entry.p: If an emergency call arrives without a subscription Id and this application preference is set to "true", an external SPR lookup is enabled.
If an emergency call arrives without a subscription Id and this application preference is set to "false", the external SPR lookup is disabled.
This system preference is used to send SLR-Intermediate without subscription Ids.
When the system preference is set to true, it excludes Subscription-Ids in SLR-Intermediate. When it is set to false, the SLR-Intermediate with Subscription-Ids is sent.
This system preference is used to send Nchf-Subscribe Update without subscription Ids.
When the system preference is set to true, it excludes Subscription-Ids in Nchf-Subscribe Update. When it is set to false, the Nchf-Subscribe Update with Subscription-Ids is sent.
If this application preference is set to true, on-call unknown device creation is not be allowed and the request is rejected.
There is no impact on emergency calls. Emergency calls, whether or not there is a sim (subid or not), are allowed to create the unknown device regardless of the application preference value.

row.entry: Flag to enable or disable VSA EDR.

entry.p: The time in minutes that must elapse before a GUI session will timeout and terminate due to inactivity.
0 disables timeouts in the SM GUI. Other application timers may cause the session to terminate after periods of server inactivity.
Parameter changes take effect at the next login.

row.entry: Gx Sessions for device exceeds configurable number
This application preference will allow a “High number of Sessions detected” alarm to be generated stating that the Gx Session Limit has been reached.
Allows the operator to delay the sending of Gx RAR messages. This is specific for RARs that are triggered as part of an incoming request (for example, CCR-I, CCR-U, etc) on the Gx interface.

entry.p: Caution: Some aspects of site routing that can be customized but use of this application preference is specific to your network configuration and must be directed by Nokia Services only. Contact the Nokia Services team for more information.
The "Gx missing mapping record strategy" allows you to specify how routing of messages should occur if no device mapping records are present for the Gx session.

row.entry: Allows you to set the amount time that a server will wait before an HTTP connection time out can occur. There can be as much as a 5 minute delay waiting for HTTP connection time out to occur if the web server is not available.

entry.p: This system preference is used to send STR including Subscription-Ids.
When the system preference is set to true, it includes Subscription-Ids in STR. When it is set to false, the system preference does not include Subscription-Ids in STR.
This preference is used to send STR including Subscription-Ids.
When the system preference is set to true, it excludes Subscription-Ids in Nchf-Terminate. When it is set to false, the Nchf-Terminate with Subscription-Ids is sent.

row.entry: The host name or IP address of the IOH.
IP-CAN ReAuth Scheduler Rate (max outbound msgs per second)

entry.p: Used to control the number of outbound messages that are sent to the interfaces and gateways connected to the policy application.
This is used for throttling the rate of RAR (Re-Auth Request) sent to PGW (packet gateway) or gateways connected with policy application.
Note: Rx RAR is not subject to this configuration.
A value of 0 indicates that this feature is disabled.

row.entry: For stale IP-CAN session audits, this audit run daily. Sessions are audited to make sure that the PCRF is not holding state in its database for a session that no longer exists on the device that requested the creation of the session.

entry.p: The number of seconds after midnight that the daily auditing of the IP-CAN session should begin (for example, 2am = 2 * 60 * 60).

row.entry: The amount of time in seconds that the audit will run (for example, to run 90 minutes = 90* 60).
The number of days old an IP-CAN session can be before it is considered “too old” and therefore eligible for auditing.

entry.p: Allows you to change the audit behavior from a daily audit to a more frequent periodic audit.
In “lab mode” when a record is first created, the timestamp is calculated as:
timestampInSecondsSinceEpoch = now + inactivity duration (in seconds, not days) + audit start time + random number in the range (0 - audit length)
When a record is audited and confirmed to still exist/be valid, the timestamp for the next audit is calculated the same way as when the record was first created.

row.entry: Used to activate a custom LDAP plugin.
Flag to enable or disable LDAP search EDR.

entry.p: If this application preference is set to “true”, a value conversion is performed to send the afChargingIdentifier in an update_notify request.
The value conversion is needed because an afChargingIdentifier has a datatype of String on the Rx interface and UINT on the N7 interface.

For example: If the value received on the Rx interface with this application preference set to “true” is: “sgc11.ocatf3.sip.lab.t-mobile.com-1565-391208-336014”, the value sent on the N7 interface needs to be the numbers after the last occurrence of “-” ( i.e. “336014”).

If this application preference is set to “false”, the value received on the Rx interface is sent on the N7 interface as it arrived without conversion. For example: “sgc11.ocatf3.sip.lab.t-mobile.com-1565-391208-336014”.
Allows you to configure a log throttling rate such that loggers are limited to a configurable number of messages per second. Loggers that exceed the threshold will be muted.
If Loggers exceed the threshold and become muted, a warning-level log message will be logged. For example:
<...> Logger being muted: log rate of 2 msgs/sec exceeds limit.
Caution: This option must only be used on lab systems. Increasing the log rate on production systems may adversely impact performance.
The default value of 2 means that muting will occur after the threshold of 2 logs/sec has been exceeded; therefore, muting would occur when the rate is at least 3 logs/sec.

row.entry: Maximum Number Of Session Audit Failed Messages

For all session types, this application preference tracks the number of failed session audit attempts until this configurable number of failed session audit attempts is reached. When the number of failed session audit attempts reaches this threshold, the session is removed from the database.
Maximum Allowed Gx Session Per Device Per APN

entry.p: If this system preference is configured with valid range from 0 to 100, then it limits (till configured value) the Gx session based on their APN for a particular device. After reaching to the configured value, New session replaces the existing session of the device with the same APN having the oldest activity time.
Note: This system preference works only if other system preference named as Replace Gx Session for different Framed-IP and same APN + SIDs is configured as false.

row.entry: Maximum Allowed PDU Session Per Device Per DNN

entry.p: If this application preference is configured with valid range from 0 to 100, then it limits (till configured value) the PDU session based on their DNN for a particular device. After reaching to the configured value, New session replaces the existing session of the device with the same APN having the oldest activity time.
Note: This system preference works even though if other system preference named PDU Session Replacement enabled is configured as false.

row.entry: Maximum Allowed Sd Session per Gx Session

entry.p: The purpose of this application preference is to limit the Number of Concurrent Sd Sessions.
If this application preference is configured with a zero (0), there is no limit (Unbounded) to the number of allowed Sd Sessions per Gx Session.

If this application preference is configured with valid range from 1 to 100, then it limits the number of concurrent Sd sessions for a given IPCAN session id for its lifetime (create/update). After reaching to the configured value, new Sd session creation will not be allowed.

If the value configured in the application preference is less than the sd sessions that already exist, then the additional existing sd sessions will not be terminated and any new concurrent Sd sessions will not be created. For example:
Maximum Allowed Sd Session Per Gx Session = 3
If the current number of Sd sessions are already 10, the extra 7 Sd sessions will not be terminated, but that means that new Sd session creation will not be allowed.

row.entry: Metering limit Priority Order - Low to High

entry.p: Used to order UCSs into a specified priority or order of precedence.

When you set this application preference to false, the priority order is reversed such that the highest priority number has the highest priority and the lowest priority number has the lowest priority.

row.entry: Metering limit Base Unit Rounding Type

entry.p: Configures the type of rounding that is applied for usage data. The following Base Unit rounding options are available to allow you to configure how the base units are rounded:

li.p: nearest - Configure rounding to the nearest value that is a multiple of the base unit (for example, values from 0 up to 0.5, but not including 0.5, round down to 0, and 0.5 to 1 round up to 1).
down - Configure rounding down to the lower value that is a multiple of the base unit (for example, values from 0 to 1 round down to 0).
up - Configure rounding up to the higher value that is a multiple of the base unit (for example, values from 0 to 1 round up to 1).

row.entry: Allows the operator to delay the sending of N7 RAR messages. This is specific for RARs that are triggered as part of an incoming request (for example, CCR-I, CCR-U, etc) on the N7 interface.
NASREQ – Fetch Device Using Calling Station Id

NASREQ call device lookups can be done using Calling-Station-Id or using Subscription-Id. If you set this application preference to “true”, the lookup is done on Calling-Station-Id. If you set this application preference to “false”, the lookup is done on Subscription-Id allowing for backwards compatibility.
Nchf Accept Notify for Failed Session

Defines whether the system accepts Nchf Notify for failed sessions. If the value of this system preference is true, then PCF accepts the Nchf_SpendingLimitControl_Notify request for a failed session and Nchf_SpendingLimitControl_Subscribe POST request is triggered towards CHF for retry of Nchf session. The Nchf_SpendingLimitControl_Subscribe POST request which is triggered consists of counters combined from both the Nchf Session (For example counter = A) in DB and the incoming Notify request (For example Counter = B). Subscribe request is triggered with both the counters A, B. In case there are no counters present in the DB, then Subscribe request sends the request for all counters. When accepting Notify request for a failed session, the RSV is not evaluated and counters are not processed. If the value of this system preference is false, then the behavior is intact as previous means it falls back to the existing behavior that is rejecting with unknown session.

For stale session audits, this audit is run daily. Sessions are audited to make sure that the PCRF is not holding state in its database for a session that no longer exists on the device that requested the creation of the session.

entry.p: Integer The number of seconds aftermidnight that the daily auditing of the Nchf session should begin (forexample, 2am = 2 * 60 * 60)

row.entry: Number of seconds between audits for Nchf Session Re-Establishments.
Nchf Session Termination Retry Audit Interval (seconds)
Number of seconds between audits for Nchf Session Termination Retries.
The amount of time in seconds that the Nchf audit will run (for example, 90minutes = 90* 60)
The number of days old an Nchf session can be before it is considered “too old” and therefore eligible for auditing.

entry.p: Allows you to change the audit behavior from a daily audit to a more frequent periodic audit. In “lab mode” when a record is first created, the timestamp is calculated as:
timestampInSecondsSinceEpoch = now + inactivity duration (in seconds, not days) + audit start time + random number inthe range (0 - audit length)
When a record is audited and confirmed to still exist/be valid, the timestamp for the next audit is calculated the same way as when the record was first created.

row.entry: Used to provide the secondary CHF address in the absense of a rule or device custom data. This URI contains the secondary CHF address to be used by PCF to communicate with CHF in case the Primary is not responding or if retries with primary have been exhausted.

entry.p: The default value shows that no value has been configured. If you need to provide the secondary CHF address, enter the value.

row.entry: Nchf Include DB Policy Counters in Nchf-Subscribe-Intermediate

entry.p: This system preference is used to Include db policy counters in Nchf-Subscribe-Intermediate which is triggered for OCS sync-up.

When an Nchf-Subscribe-Intermediate is triggered for an Nchf Session on Gx-I or N7-Create for CHF sync up, if the Nchf Include DB Policy Counters in Nchf-Subscribe-Intermediate system preference is true, then the DB policy counters are sent. If it is false the policy-counter-identifier attribute is not sent indicating the request of all counters.

row.entry: Nchf Include DB Policy Counters in Periodic Nchf-Subscribe-Initial

entry.p: This system preference is used to include db policy counters in Nchf-Subscribe-Initial is triggered after periodically triggered Nchf-Subscribe-Intermediate is responded with 5002.

When Nchf-Subscribe-Initial is triggered after 5002 is received in Nchf-Subscribe-Intermediate which is triggered by a periodic task. Nchf-Subscribe-Initial includes db policy-counters, if the system preference Nchf Include DB Policy Counters in Periodic Nchf-Subscribe-Initial is set to true.
Enables CHF on the devices for the N28 interface.

If you are using the application preferences: “Nchf CHF Enabled” and “Nchf CHF Target Uri”, “Nchf CHF Enabled” must be set to true and “Nchf CHF Target Uri” must be set to the CHF URI value. You must also include the DSC.notifUri action under the PDU or IPCAN Session Establishment triggers as a rule to provide the PCF URI and trigger the N28 session.

This is used by the PCF to send an N28 message to the CHF. When PCF wants to subscribe to count information, it needs to use this value to send the message to the CHF. It is also a mandatory parameter for the N28 interface to work.

If you are using the application preferences: “Nchf CHF Enabled” and “Nchf CHF Target Uri”, “Nchf CHF Enabled” must be set to true and “Nchf CHF Target Uri” must be set to the CHF URI value. You must also include the DSC.notifUri action under the PDU or IPCAN Session Establishment triggers as a rule to provide the PCF URI and trigger the N28 session.
Enter the http URL for the CHF service.

row.entry: Defines the amount of time policy application waits for the initial or intermediate Nchf_SpendingLimitControl_Subscribe-Request/Nchf_SpendingLimitControl_Subscribe-Answer exchange and Nchf_SpendingLimitControl_Unsubscribe-Request/Nchf_SpendingLimitControl_Unsubscribe-Answer exchange to complete before replying to the SMF with the policy decision. Here you can set the amount of time that can elapse before policy application times out waiting for the Nchf response to the Nchf request.

entry.p: Note: Setting this value to 0 indicates that there is no wait time and N7 service starts immediately.

row.entry: This is the counter value to retry primary CHF and Secondary CHF.
Nchf Update For Active Session On Initial

entry.p: This system preference is used to trigger N28-Intermediate on each N7-Create Request (Gx-CCR-I/N7-create)
When this system preference is true, an Nchf-Update is triggered towards the CHF on the receipt of every new CCR-I/N7-Create over the Gx/N7 interface if there is a connected Nchf existing for device.

row.entry: Nchf Update For Active Session Audit Duration (seconds)

entry.p: This system preference is used to send Nchf-Intermediate periodically.

Periodic triggering of SLR-Intermediate to the OCS is controlled using this System Preference which holds the period interval value. If configured as 0, then feature is considered disabled. If periodicity feature is ON, then triggering of SLR-Intermediate on every new Gx-CCR-I/N7-Create is automatically OFF.
Allows you to configure the format that will be displayed for the date and time variables in notifications. This has no affect on how Date and Time is applied on any other aspect of the system.
You can use the default format or if you want another format, just type in one of the supported SimpleDateFormats.
The default format is the standard XML date format:
See the following for more information about SimpleDataFormats:

li.p: MMM dd, yyyy hh:mm:ss a z
MMM dd, yyyy hh:mm:ss a z Z
MMMM dd, yyyy hh:mm:ss a z
MMMM dd, yyyy hh:mm:ss a z Z

entry.p: Note: If you are using the ASR console, this appears as NetLocNoGatewaySupport
Applies when the NetLoc bit is not set in the Supported-Features AVP by the gateway during an IP-CAN session establishment.

Note: If a Dummy RAR action is present for an AF Establishment or AF Modification, and the AAR message contains the specific action ACCESS_NETWORK_INFO_REPORT with Required Access Info equal to 0, the Dummy RAR is sent towards Gx to get the user location information (received at PCRF as the result of the Dummy RAR response), the user location information is reported in the 3GPP-User-Location-Info AVP in the AAA.
This field can have one of three different values:

li.p: When this application preference is configured to No Report and the PCEF does not support the NetLoc feature, the PCRF responds to the AF NetLoc request to indicate that NetLoc is not supported. This is 3GPP standard behavior.

Upon receiving the NetLoc request from the AF, the PCRF behaves as if NetLoc is supported by the PCEF. It sends the NetLoc request to the PCEF and expects a one-time access network information report from the PCEF. This option is designed to support PCEFs that implemented the 3gpp standard NetLoc function without setting the NetLoc feature bit.

When this application preference is configured to Multiple Reports, the PCRF is able to respond to AF NetLoc initial requests even if the PCEF has no NetLoc function, provided that the user location information is included in the IP-CAN session initial request. The PCRF reports to the AF every time it receives a location information from the gateway, regardless of any subsequent AF requests.
If an AAR message contains the specific action ACCESS_NETWORK_INFO_REPORT with Required Access Info equal to 0, the user location is reported in the AAA.
If the user location is present in the Gx session, the 3GPP-User-Location-Info AVP is sent in the AAA.
If the user location is not present in the Gx session, the 3GPP-SGSN-MCC-MNC AVP is sent in the AAA.

row.entry: NetLoc - Default Flow Description for ANI Requests

entry.p: The NetLoc - Default Flow Description for ANI Requests applies to AF NPLI requests with no service information provided in the AF session request. The PCRF generates a PCC rule with the flow information provided by this application preference, and includes the Required-Access-Info from the AF request in the PCC rule. The IP-CAN session default bearer QCI is assigned to this PCC rule.

The default value of “NetLoc - Default Flow Description for ANI Requests” is a pair of wild card bidirectional flows. It is able to take a single downlink or single uplink direction flow. It is also possible to take an empty value. In this case, the resulting PCC rule is a pair of wild card bidirectional flows.
action direction proto from src and to dst
Default: permit out ip from any to any
The only action supported is “permit”. That could be “permit out ip from any to any” or “permit in ip from any to any” “direction”
Specifies the direction as in or out.
Rules that specify in are only applied to packets coming from the terminal.
Rules that specify out are only applied to packets being sent to the terminal.
An IP protocol specified by number. The “ip” keyword means any protocol will match.
Specifies the IP addresses to match.
The <address/mask> can be specified as follows:
An IPv4 or IPv6 number in dotted-quad or canonical IPv6 form. Only this exact IP number will match the rule.

row.entry: NetLoc - Default Flow Description for ANI Requests(continued)

An IP number as above with a mask width of the form 1.2.3.4/24. In this case, all IP numbers from 1.2.3.0 to 1.2.3.255 will match. The bit width MUST be valid for the IP version and the IP number MUST NOT have bits set beyond the mask. For a match to occur, the same IP version must be present in the packet that was used in describing the IP address. To test for a particular IP version, the bits part can be set to zero. The keyword "any" is 0.0.0.0/0 or the IPv6 equivalent. The keyword "assigned" is the address or set of addresses assigned to the terminal. For IPv4, a typical first rule is often "deny in ip! assigned". The sense of the match can be inverted by preceding an address with the not modifier (!), causing all other addresses to be matched instead. This does not affect the selection of port numbers.
NetLoc - Default Flow Description for ANI Requests(continued)

entry.p: Port number or numbers. You can enter a single port or a list of ports. With the TCP, UDP and SCTP protocols, optional ports may be specified as:
{port/port-port}[,ports(,...)] The '-' notation specifies a range of ports (including boundaries).

Fragmented packets that have a non-zero offset (for example, not the first fragment) will never match a rule that has one or more port specifications. See the frag option for details on matching fragmented packets.

row.entry: NetLoc - Replace PCC Rules on service info status transition

entry.p: This parameter defines the policy application behavior when the AF session final service information is received in an AF session update request, if a previously received NPLI request includes preliminary service information.
During the NPLI preliminary service request, a preliminary PCC rule is created by the policy application with the QCI of the IP-CAN session default bearer.
When the final service AF request is received and this application preference value is “false”, the PCRF updates the PCC rule with the media service QCI, defined by the media-type in the request.
If the value is set to “true”, the PCRF creates a new PCC rule based on the final service AF request and removes the previous PCC rule installed during the preliminary service request.

row.entry: NetLoc - Rx STA Delay Waiting for ANI Report (seconds)

Applies to NPLI requests during AF session termination only. When the policy application receives an AF session termination request with the Required-Access-Info AVP, it generates a Gx RAR with a corresponding access network information request to the gateway and starts a timer, waiting for access network (ANI) report from the gateway. If the PCRF receives an access network information report from the gateway before the timer expires, the PCRF responds to the AF with the access network information in the AF session termination response message (STA). If the PCRF does not receive an access network information report from the gateway before the timer expires, an STA is sent without the access network information.
Auto Subscription is performed only when system preference for NRF Auto Subscription is enabled.
This preference is used to mention protocol for the call back URI of the auto subscriptions.

This application preference is used to configure the Overload threshold and allows calls to be distributed within the same priority band using the load ratio. Load ratio is calculated as per the available capacity of other CHFs.

This application preference is used to provide a normalization factor for the capacity ratio used for call distribution so that the distribution proportion can be recalculated based on the updated Discovery Query cache.
This preference is used to mention FQDN as replacement of IOHD IP to create call back URI of auto subscription.

entry.p: The default time period that policy application uses to form the validityTime parameter of the NF-Subscribe and NF-Subscription-Update message towards the NRF.
For auto-subscriptions, the value is picked from this preference.
For UI created Subscriptions, you can override this value by specifying the value in the “Validity Interval” field.

row.entry: This flag enables or disables the policy support for NRF metrics. If set to true, metrics related to NRF gets captured. Restart is not required for any change in the feature flag.
NRF: Interface for CallBack IP address

entry.p: This application preference gives the interface to be used for extracting external IP address (VIP) of IOHD. This IP address is used further for creating call back URI in NFStatusSubscribe, that is the URI on which NFStatusNotify is received.

Note: Since the call back URI is calculated and saved in DB while creating NFSubscription, any update in this system preference parameter will not affect already created NFSubscriptions. To update already created NFsubscription’s, the call back URI must be un-provisioned (will trigger NFStatusUnSubscribe) and provisioned again (will trigger NFStatusSubscribe).

row.entry: This is the flag that enables or disables the policy support for NRF. If set to “true”, all policy features are enabled. No restart is required for any change in the feature flag.

This is the buffer time in milliseconds to account for the communication between the NF-handler component (which sits on the application nodes) and the controller component (which is installed on the OAME node).
Time interval in seconds, between two runs of the NF Discovery daemon thread. This daemon thread scans the NF discovery cache and refreshes any expired/not present NF discovery queries.

entry.p: This application preference is for information purposes and is not visible from the SM GUI.

This value is expressed as a percentage (%) of the NF heartbeat time. The NF heartbeat for a registered NF is sent a little earlier than the expiry of the heartbeat interval for that NF. For example, if the heartbeat interval for a NF is 10 seconds and 'NRF Heartbeat Buffer' is set to 20, the NF heart-beat is sent 2 seconds before the expiry of 10 seconds.

row.entry: It defines the locality of the PCF on an ME. The value is used to identify primary and secondary Region values of CHF.

entry.p: By default this value is “true”. When this is “true”, PDU Session Replacement is enabled for PDU sessions.
When this value is set to “false, PDU Session Replacement is disabled for PDU sessions.

row.entry: Set this property to "true" when CCR-T must be processed forcefully when lock has already been acquired by RAR and the CCR-T has to be processed forcefully. In this case, CCR-T is processed without taking the lock on device.

The PCRF can be configured for early video removal. If configured to true, the PCRF removes the dedicated video bearer before informing the Rx side about the handover. Upon receiving the Session-Termination-Request, the PCRF also removes any remaining bearers.

entry.p: Used in the usage arming calculation to allocate next quota and is related to the Default Volume Quota (bytes) application preferences such that the value used for usage arming on the PCEF is the lowest of [usage until next threshold, Quota Allocation Factor (%), and Default Volume Quota (bytes)].
Lower Quota Allocation Factor (%) values may cause a significant increase in transaction rate, and must be considered in platform sizing.

row.entry: Reauth Scheduler Buffer Size offers a means to control outbound message loss by using a buffer to queue the related reauthorization tasks. As the reauthorization tasks are about to run, they enter into the buffer where they wait in a queue. The size of that buffer can be configured here such that when the configured value is reached, any new tasks that try to enter the buffer are rejected. A lower outbound message rate will result as you lower the value configured for this application preference.
The delay that can be added to the audit start time task from when a peer is detected to have a new OSI. It configures how far in the future from that time the auditing tasks should begin.
The maximum number of audits/second that should be generated across all application blades (each application blade generates 1/N of the events).
The age that an “auditTriggerTime” field in a stale/out-of-date DiameterPeer object can be before it is assumed that the audit is no longer running, but has failed or has been aborted.
Remove Sy Session on STR Failure

entry.p: If true is configured, when an STR triggered towards the OCS fails, the PCRF immediately deletes the Sy session instead of marking it for audit, if it does not have any Gx associations. For transient failures, the default behavior is followed (PCRF will do an immediate retry).
If false is configured, when an STR triggered towards OCS fails, the PCRF marks the Sy session as terminating and it's cleaning is handled using the TEM audit. This is the default policy behavior.

row.entry: Replace Gx Session for different Framed-IP and same APN + SIDs

entry.p: If this application preference is set to “true”, policy application replaces the existing Gx session when a Gx CCR-I is received with the same APN and Subscription-ID combination but the Framed-IP-Address is different. If this application preference is required to be “true”, the value should be set to “true” at the time of initial deployment and it is not recommended to change after that.
If this application preference is set to “false”, a new Gx session is created.

row.entry: Use this to configure the number of seconds a client must wait to retry its request for a resource from a server. It is used to give the client a specific number of seconds at which it should retry its request.
The value to use for Origin-State-Id if "RFC-3588: Use if Compliant Origin-State-Id" is set to false.

entry.p: When set to true, the policy application increments its Origin State Id in a way that is compliant with RFC-3588 when it loses state or is operating in a geo-redundant deployment and the other site has advertised a newer OSI than the site that it is starting to listen to for Diameter connections. When a Diameter server such as the policy application receives an incremented client OSI, it assumes that sessions that were active under the previous OSI have been terminated.
When this preference is set to false the policy application uses the value indicated by RFC-3588: Non-Compliant Origin-State-Id Value.
If this application preference is set to false, the application preference “Client Origin State-Id Validation" must be set to true to allow them to accept the connections from each other.
Note: If you are using the ASR console, this appears as:

According to 3GPP speifications, when the PCEF reports to the PCRF that all the flows of a dynamic PCC rule are terminated, the PCRF shall send Rx:ASR to tell the IMS to abort the AF session. If only some of the flows have been terminated, the PCRF informs the AF about this via Rx:RAR. This is the default behavior when the application preference is set to “false”. However, some IMS systems react too quickly and send an STR, which results in failed PS to CS handover scenarios.

For cases when the bearers have been reported with Rule-Failure-Code= PS_TO_CS_HANDOVER (13), the application preference “RxRAR For PS2CS Handover Enabled” allows you to set the field to “true”, which causes the policy application to send an Rx-RAR when all dedicated bearers are affected. That is, the policy application sends an RxRAR towards the AF when the PCEF reports that all the dedicated bearers for the AF session are removed.
If both the Suppress ASR on CCR-T and RxRAR for PS2CS Handover Enabled application preferences are set to true, the ASR from the PCRF to the AF is suppressed.

row.entry: Used to delay the sending of an Rx RAR message. If AF registers for ACCESS_NETWORK_INFO_ REPORT on an AF establishment for access to network information report, an Rx RAR message will be sent immediately with the information if the access network information requested is already available on IP-CAN.

entry.p: Note: If you are using ASR console, this appears as RuleBaseChangeEnabled.

This application preference supports PCC rule base name changes that allow the rulebase name to change without losing the active rules defined within the rulebase. The support of PCC rule base name changes is optional such that you can enable or disable this functionality using the application preference “RuleBase Change Enabled”.
When the application preference is set to true:

li.p: The policy application sends all PCC rule related actions to the gateway.

When the remove-all action is encountered, and the final rule engine actions show that the Charging Rule Base Name is changing, The policy application sends only the removal of the Charging Rule Base Name to the gateway, however internally it removes all other Charging Rule Names from the session. The policy rules sent to the gateway include the new Charging Rule Base Name and all required PCC rules, even those that may have been previously applied to the session are re-deployed as part of the new Charging Rule Base Name deployment.

When the remove-all action is encountered, and the final actions show that the Charging Rule Base Name does not change, policy application sends only the delta values to the gateway. For example, if CRBN_1, CRN_A, CRN_B, CRN_C, changes to CRBN_1, CRN_A, CRN_B, CRN_D, policy application sends the rule removal for CRN_C and a rule install for CRN_D, there is no need to redeploy the same base-rule.

entry.p: Enables the collection of rule metrics for the PCRF rules application.
There are two counters. One for the number of times each rule is matched and one for the number of times each rule table is executed without having a rule matched.
Number of seconds between audits for rule status changes.
In geo-redundant configurations, the Rule Status Change Audit will run for the geo-mate's sessions, after the configured number of seconds, only if the site has been declared down.

row.entry: Allows you to turn rule engine trace logging on or off for the PCRF rules applications. This logging provides a very detailed description of the evaluation process for the rule engine and is used to assist in debugging problems. The log content is directed to the file: /opt/tpa/logs/PolicyDecision.log.

For stale S9 session audits, this audit run daily. Sessions are audited to make sure that the PCRF is not holding state in its database for a session that no longer exists on the device that requested the creation of the session.

entry.p: The number of seconds after midnight that the daily auditing of the S9 session should begin (for example, 2am = 2 * 60 * 60)

row.entry: The amount of time in seconds that the S9 audit will run (for example, 90 minutes = 90* 60)
The number of days old an S9 session can be before it is considered “too old” and therefore eligible for auditing.

entry.p: Allows you to change the audit behavior from a daily audit to a more frequent periodic audit.
In “lab mode” when a record is first created, the timestamp is calculated as:
timestampInSecondsSinceEpoch = now + inactivity duration (in seconds, not days) + audit start time + random number in the range (0 - audit length)
When a record is audited and confirmed to still exist/be valid, the timestamp for the next audit is calculated the same way as when the record was first created.

Define the amount of time policy application waits for the initial TSR/TSA exchange to complete before replying to the PGW with the policy decision. Here you can set the amount of time that can elapse before policy application times out waiting for the Sd response to the Sd request.
Note: This value cannot be greater than Diameter stack time-out. (ETCD key name: diameteragentcfg/diameteragent/client/timeout)
Note: Setting this value to 0 indicates that there is no wait time and Gx will be the service immediately.

row.entry: Number of seconds between audits for Sd Session Re-Establishments.
Sd Session Termination Retry Audit Interval (seconds)
Number of seconds between audits for Sd Session Termination Retries.

This audit runs daily for stale Sd session audits. Sessions are audited to make sure that the PCRF is not holding state in its database for a session that no longer exists on the device that requested the creation of the session.

entry.p: The number of seconds after midnight that the daily auditing of the Sy session should begin (for example, 2am = 2 * 60 * 60)

row.entry: The amount of time in seconds that the Sd audit will run (for example, 90 minutes = 90* 60)
The number of days an Sd session can exist before it is considered “too old” and therefore eligible for auditing.

entry.p: Allows you to change the audit behavior from a daily audit to a more frequent periodic audit.
In “lab mode” when a record is first created, the timestamp is calculated as:
timestampInSecondsSinceEpoch = now + inactivity duration (in seconds, not days) + audit start time + random number in the range (0 - audit length)
When a record is audited and confirmed to still exist/be valid, the timestamp for the next audit is calculated the same way as when the record was first created.

row.entry: The number of seconds (or duration) that audits for Sd Session Re-establishment and Termination Retries can last.

entry.p: This system preference is used to prioritize the processing of Gx CCR-T messages.
The default value is 0, where the preference is disabled. It is enabled when it is set to a value greater than 0.

Assuming Session TEM Reschedule Offset (seconds) is set to a value greater than 0 and a Gx CCR-T arrives at the policy application with policy unable to process the request as busy in another task/s, policy application updates the TEMEntity with the current time stamp and Session TEM Reschedule Offset (seconds) in Epoch format so that Audit starts the processing based on the timestamp. In this case, policy application returns 2001 diameter code with error message “Error-Code DIAMETER_TOO_BUSY Overridden, Message is scheduled for processing.”.

The policy application schedules an independent process for immediate processing of the Gx CCR-T. If the immediate processing is successful, it cleans up that IPCANSession. If immediate processing is unsuccessful or failed, then Audit picks up this session for clean-up.

If a GX CCR-I arrives at the policy application, then it checks the TEM entries on all other IPCANSessions of that device. If TEM entries are missing for those IPCANSessions, then the new TEM entries are created for those IPCANSessions. A later Audit picks up these IPCANSessions for clean up.

li.p: ALL: CDRs for all requests were processed by SiteRouting Plugin.
ALL_SUCCESS: CDRs for all requests were routed successfully by SiteRouting Plugin.
ALL_FAILED: CDRs for all requests were rejected by SiteRouting Plugin.
CROSS_SITE: CDRs for cross-site requests were processed by SiteRouting Plugin.
CROSS_SITE_SUCCESS: CDRs for cross-site requests were routed successfully by SiteRouting Plugin.
CROSS_SITE_FAILED: CDRs for cross-site requests were rejected by SiteRouting Plugin.
NONE: Flag is disabled. No CDR for site routing

row.entry: This application preference decides whether to bind Gx Session with ALC-IPv6-Address (VSA) present in CCR initial request. If this system preference's value is true and only ALC-IPv6-Address is present in the request all other IP-addresses (that is, IPv4, Framed-IPv6, and Delegated-IPv6-Prefix) are not present, then GX Session binds with ALC-IPv6-Address.

This application preference specifies whether to support complete 128-bit in IPV6 addresses which are considered only 64-bit out of 128-bit. Currently, the policy application supports only 64-bit (out of 128-bit) in Framed-IPv6-Prefix address. When this system preference's value is true, complete 128-bit is considered in Framed-IPv6-Prefix address.

entry.p: If set to "true", when a PS_TO_CS_HANDOVER is reported in a CCR-U from the PGW which leads to a Rx-RAR with Abort-Cause=PS_TO_CS_HANDOVER, then the Rx-ASR is suppressed by the policy application when the CCR-T is received from the PGW.
If both the Suppress ASR on CCR-T and RxRAR for PS2CS Handover Enabled application preferences are set to true, the ASR from the PCRF to the AF is suppressed.
If set to "false, the default behavior is followed.

row.entry: Suppress Gx RAR when no change in QoS

entry.p: If set to "true", a Gx-RAR will not be triggered if there is no change in Policy related parameters concerning QoS-Information, Charging-Rule-Install, Charging-Rule-Remove, or the registration of new Event-Triggers on the PGW, etc. to name a few. In the case that the Gx-RAR contains only VSA related information like PCRF-Mapping-Parameters or PCRF-Error-Detail, then policy application does not trigger a RAR.
If set to "false, then the default behavior is followed.

If this preference is set to “true”, then the Gx-RAR is suppressed by the policy application when a Device Delete request is reported or when a subscription identifier corresponding to the device is deleted or updated.
If set to “false”, the default behavior is followed, which means that policy application triggers a Gx-RAR with the Session-Release-Cause=UE Subscription Changed Reason.

row.entry: Sy Accept SNR for Failed Session

Define whether system accepts SNR for failed sessions. If the value of this system preference is true, then PCRF accepts the SNR for failed session and SLR-Intermediate is triggered towards OCS for retry of Sy Session. The SLR-Intermediate which is triggered consists of counters combined from both the Sy Session (For example counter = A) in DB and the incoming SNR (For example counter = B). SLR-Intermediate counters = A,B. In case there are no counters present in the DB, then SLR intermediate sends the request to all counters. If the SLR-Intermediate is rejected with 5002 error code, then SLR-initial is sent with the same content as SLR-Intermediate based on this system preference. When accepting SNR for a failed Sy session, the RSV is not evaluated and the counters are not processed. If the value of this system preference is false, then the behavior is intact as previous means it falls back to the existing behavior (SNR rejected with 5002 error code).
Sy Include DB Policy Counters in SLR-Intermediate

entry.p: This system preference is used to Include db policy counters in SLR-Intermediate which is triggered for OCS sync-up.

When an SLR-Intermediate is triggered for an Sy Session on Gx-I or N7-Create for OCS sync up, if the Sy Include DB Policy Counters in SLR-Intermediate system preference is true, then the DB policy counters are sent. If it is false the policy-counter-identifier AVP is not sent indicating the request of all counters.

row.entry: Sy Include DB Policy Counters in Periodic SLR-Initial

entry.p: To include db policy counters in SLR-Initial triggered after periodically triggered SLR-Intermediate responded with 5002.

When SLR-Initial is triggered after 5002 is received in SLR-Intermediate which is triggered by periodic task, this SLR-Initial includes db policy-counters if the system preference Sy Include DB Policy Counters in Periodic SLR-Initial is true.

row.entry: Sy Maximum Pending Status Per Policy Counter
Allows you to limit Pending-Policy-Counter-Information instances within a Policy-Counter-Status-Report.

entry.p: The configured value of “0” means that there is no limit.

row.entry: Enables OCS on the devices for the Sy interface.
Enables Diameter communication with OCS over Sy interface.
Enter the realm of the OCS.
Sy Maximum Pending Status Per Policy Counter
Configuring a value here limits the number of Pending-Policy-Counter-Information instances within a Policy-Counter-Status-Report.

entry.p: Define the amount of time policy application will wait for the initial or intermediate SLR/SLA exchange and STR/STA exchange to complete before replying to the PGW with the policy decision. Here you can set the amount of time that can elapse before policy application times out waiting for the Sy response to the Sy request.
Note: If the response to a Sy request exceeds the configured timeout, or an unsuccessful SLA response for SLR request occurs, logs similar to the following are displayed on the PSB:
Received unsuccessful SLAresponse for SLR request:

<YYYY.MM.DD HH:MM:SS XXX-XXXX><W><HOSTNAME><pool-XX-thread-X><com.nokia.tpapps.pcrf.server.statemanagement.sy.SySessionManager:718> Received unsuccessfulSLA response for SLR request, sid =SYSESSIONID;
Note: Setting this value to 0 indicates that there is no wait time and Gx will be the service immediately.

row.entry: For stale Sy session audits, this audit run daily. Sessions are audited to make sure that the PCRF is not holding state in its database for a session that no longer exists on the device that requested the creation of the session.

entry.p: The number of seconds after midnight that the daily auditing of the Sy session should begin (for example, 2am = 2 * 60 * 60)

row.entry: The amount of time in seconds that the Sy audit will run (for example, 90 minutes = 90* 60)
This parameter is used by PCRF to signify the number of days a policy Sy session must pass without any updates before it is considered “too old” and therefore eligible for auditing.

entry.p: Allows you to change the audit behavior from a daily audit to a more frequent periodic audit.
In “lab mode” when a record is first created, the timestamp is calculated as:
timestampInSecondsSinceEpoch = now + inactivity duration (in seconds, not days) + audit start time + random number in the range (0 - audit length)
When a record is audited and confirmed to still exist/be valid, the timestamp for the next audit is calculated the same way as when the record was first created.

row.entry: Number of seconds between audits for Sy Session Re-Establishments.
Sy Session Termination Retry Audit Interval (seconds)
Number of seconds between audits for Sy Session Termination Retries.
Sy SLR Re-Establishment with an Intermediate

entry.p: Define whether the SLR-Intermediate is triggered in place of SLR-Initial while retrying Sy Session. If the value of this system preference is true, then instead of SLR-Initial on Sy Session retry, SLR-Intermediate is triggered with same content as of SLR-Initial, if the value of this system preference is false, then the behavior is intact as previous means it falls back to existing behavior.
Note: For this parameter to take effect, Disable Sy Session Re-Establishment Audit has to be set to true.

row.entry: Sy SLR-Intermediate For Active Session On Initial

entry.p: This system preference is used to trigger SLR-Intermediate on each initial request (Gx-CCR-I/N7-create).

When this system preference is true, an SLR-Intermediate is triggered towards the OCS on the receipt of every new CCR-I/N7-Create over the Gx/N7 interface if there is a connected Sy existing for device

row.entry: Sy SLR-Intermediate For Active Session Audit Duration (seconds)

entry.p: This system preference is used to send SLR-Intermediate periodically.

Periodic triggering of SLR-Intermediate to the OCS is controlled using this System Preference which holds the period interval value. If configured as 0, then feature is considered disabled. If periodicity feature is ON, then triggering of SLR-Intermediate on every new Gx-CCR-I/N7-Create is automatically OFF.
Note: If you are using the ASR console, this appears as ToDRoundingParameterValue.
This application preference allows the PCRF to reduce the amount of messaging in the case when a network message is received too close to the end of a ToD interval.

For example, consider the time interval Monday 02:00:00 - Monday 08:00:00. Assume ToD Rounding parameter is set to 120 seconds (2 min).User attaches at 01:58:10. Message comes too close to the start of interval. Rounding parameter value is added to user time to match with the intervals configured in Device. Now the user time is 02:00:10. Time 02.00.10 is matched with interval Monday 02:00:00 - Monday 08:00:00. See the section “ToD Blocking Enabled” for more information.
When set to true and the policy application receives a UD Add operation request, the policy application will add the device that was fetched from the external SPR in to the local database.
When set to false and the policy application receives a UD Add operation request, the policy application will reject the request.
Indicates the DN pattern for the Ud notification.
This field is mandatory for completeness. Although it is not used, it requires that a pattern is entered in the field.
Any valid regular expression. For example:
Indicates the pattern used to extract the identifier.
This field is mandatory for completeness. Although it is not used, it requires that a pattern is entered in the field.
Any valid regular expression. For example:
Indicates the type of identifier that is carried by the associated value.
This field is mandatory for completeness. Although it is not used, it requires that a Type is entered in the field.
Values can be one of the following:
Values can be one of the following:
Indicates the Ud notification rerouting mode and can only be used in geo-redundant configurations.
Note: In split-brain and mate down scenarios in a geo-redundancy system, requests are processed locally even though the device may not belong to the site and the REDIRECT option is selected.
Values can be one of the following:

li.p: REDIRECT—you must use the Web Access Address
NONE—you do not need the Web Access Address

entry.p: The unknown device expiry time in the local database.

The number of seconds after which unknown device data expires. If not specified or set to a negative value, the device data never expires. If the expiry time is 0, the device data always expires and a new record is retrieved from the LDAP server. If the expiry time is 300 s, the Unknown device data expires 300 s after the session is established with the remote LDAP sever.
0, or any positive or negative integer

row.entry: Unknown Device Identifier(IMSI, E164 or NONE)

entry.p: This property is used to set the device ID of an unknown device created in the policy Gx CCR(Initial), if the corresponding device is not present in the system. The following options are available:

li.p: NONE: The unknown device ID is set as per default.
E164: The unknown device ID is set to the value of E164, if present in the policy Gx CCR(Initial).
IMSI: The unknown device ID is set to the value of IMSI, if present in the policy Gx CCR(Initial).

entry.p: Provides a configurable duration of time in seconds before the record of a device with no sessions is deleted from an external SPR.
The Unused Device Expiry time is only applicable to Known LDAP devices. Unused device audits depend on successful known device audits as governed by the Device Data Expiry timer.

Known devices are audited, updated when they expire, and then checked for a session attachment. If the unused device expiry time is reached for the known device, the unused Device is marked for cleanup. If no session attachment occurs until the next audit run, the known unused device without a session is deleted at next audit time.
Nokia recommends to always have Unused Device Expiry Time (seconds) timer set equal to or less than the Device Data Expiry Time (seconds) so that it can take effect.

A minimum of 2 audit runs are required to remove the unused device after the timer expires for the known device. It is possible that more than two audit runs are necessary if there is a failover, where the newly active VM needs to execute another audit again to decide if the known device qualifies as unused or not.
This application preference only applies when the SPR type is the External SPR option (LDAP).

row.entry: Use Unknown Prefix in Unknown Device

entry.p: This system preference is used for removal of unknown keyword from the name of device.
If it is being set to true, then unknown devices are created as it was done earlier.
If it is set to false, then unknown devices are created in the following new formats.
Note: In the above formats, the text in bold is fixed, and the rest of the text is created dynamically.

section.title: Supported Change Request specifications for Policy

entry.p: In the case of resource URI not found for specific URL, the policy application returns 501 in status code.
In the case of the HTTP method not implemented, the policy application returns 405 in status code.
Support for the following result codes has been added:

row.entry: #201: Remove two values of failure codes

entry.p: Following FailureCodes have been removed from the policy application:

A new action has been introduced QosCharacteristics_PacketErrRate_String in addition to the existing QosCharacteristics action. This new action has been introduced to allow configuration of PacketErrRate as string parameter in the action.
The action configured is only picked from rules when the Compliancy support system preference is set to true.

row.entry: Whenever the policy application rejects a subscribe request on the N7 interface, it includes suppFeat attribute in ProblemDetails IE. The NF Service Consumer cannot determine the features (and thereforequery parameters) supported by an NF Service Producer when the latter rejects a request.
